author: detroitnews.com
title: Lions fire coordinator Lombardi, two OL coaches
text:
Joe Lombardi (Photo: Daniel Mears, Detroit News) 
Allen Park — Just hours after coach Jim Caldwell said he didn’t plan to change his coaching staff, the team is indeed making adjustments.
The Lions fired offensive coordinator Joe Lombardi, offensive line coach Jeremiah Washburn and assistant offensive line coach Terry Heffernan Monday.
With Lombardi out after just 23 regular-season games, the Lions will promote quarterbacks coach Jim Bob Cooter to offensive coordinator, the first time he’ll hold the position in the NFL.
The Lions also will move assistant head coach Ron Prince to offensive line coach after he spent the previous two seasons working with tight ends. Special teams assistant Devin Fitzsimmons will move to tight ends coach.
The Lions (1-6) allowed seven sacks and 13 quarterback hits Sunday in a 28-19 loss to the Minnesota Vikings. The offense scored touchdowns on its first two possessions before scoring just three points the rest of the game.
Jim Bob Cooter is pictured with Matthew Stafford in training camp.   (Photo: Daniel Mears, Detroit News) 
The Lions rank 20th in yards and 29th in points per game despite having talented playmakers like Calvin Johnson, Golden Tate, Eric Ebron, Ameer Abdullah and Theo Riddick. Quarterback Matthew Stafford has also regressed overall as a player the past two years despite the Lions hiring Lombardi to help improve his game after working with Saints star Drew Brees the previous seven years.
lthough the Lions went 11-5 in 2014 in the first year under Caldwell and Lombardi, the offense was problematic during the season that resulted in a first-round playoff exit. The Lions ranked 19th in total offense and 22nd in points per game despite having a similarly talented team with a more veteran offensive line.
The Lions are due to fly to London Monday night for next Sunday’s game against the Kansas City Chiefs. Although Monday’s firings signal a monumental change, there’s no telling if falling to 1-7 could force the front office or ownership to continue altering the coaching staff.
